utils.async package¶

Submodules¶

utils.async.lock module¶

async.lock module provides a asynchronous RWLock working on top of asyncio Event

class utils.async.lock.AsyncRWLock[source]¶

Bases: object

A multiple read/single write lock asynchronous implementation of asyncio lock providing locking context with specific lock policy (read/write)

class Permissions[source]¶

Bases: enum.Enum

Three possible states: none read write

none = 0¶
read = 1¶
write = 2¶
context(permission: utils.async.lock.AsyncRWLock.Permissions)[source]¶

Create guard context with permission guard

Args:
permission: The permission to lock with
lock()[source]¶

Lock the guard for writing when there is no more reader r_lock calls will now wait for the write lock to be unlocked

r_lock()[source]¶

Lock the guard for reading, can be multiple readers if lock has been called, wait until unlock is done

r_unlock()[source]¶

Unlock the guard for reading, if there is no more reader, unlock the lock for writing

read_context()[source]¶

Create guard context with read guard

unlock()[source]¶

Unlock the guard for writing, waiting readers are notified and can acquire the lock

write_context()[source]¶

Create guard context with write guard

utils.async.waitgroup module¶

waitgroup module provides asynchronous read/write lock and wait groups classes

class utils.async.waitgroup.CancellableWaitGroup[source]¶

Bases: utils.async.waitgroup.WaitGroup

A waitgroup that can cancel all tasks added to it, calling add when the task is added, and done when the tasks has completed.

The CancellableWaitGroup keeps track of running tasks added to the group and provides two additional functions compared to the simplier WaitGroup class. The run method wraps coroutines in a task and add them to the wait group. Each tasks has a callback set to decrement the WaitGroup counter as they finish.

add_async(coro_or_future: typing.Coroutine) → _asyncio.Task[source]¶

calls add, schedule the execution of a coroutine object: wrap it in a future, calls done when the future is done. Return a Task object.

Args:
coro_or_future: a coroutine or :class: asyncio.Future object: wrapped it in a future
Raises:
  • RuntimeError: If the same task is added multiple time before it completes
  • TypeError: If coro_or_future is neithe a coroutine nor a future
Returns:
The wrapped coroutine
cancel_all()[source]¶

Cancel all cancels all managed tasks

class utils.async.waitgroup.WaitGroup[source]¶

Bases: object

WaitGroup simple implementation with asyncio.

A WaitGroup waits for a collection of coroutines to finish. The main coroutine calls add to set the number of coroutines to wait for. Then each of the coroutine runs and calls done when finished. At the same time, wait can be used to block until all coroutines have finished.

add(delta: int = 1)[source]¶

Add adds delta, which may be negative, to the WaitGroup counter. If the counter becomes zero, all coroutines blocked on Wait are released. If the counter goes negative, add raises a RuntimeError.

Note that calls with a positive delta that occur when the counter is zero must happen before a wait. Calls with a negative delta, or calls with a positive delta that start when the counter is greater than zero, may happen at any time. Typically this means the calls to add should execute before the statement creating the coroutine or other event to be waited for.

Args:
delta (int, optional): The number of coroutines to add or substract from the waitgroup.
Raises:
RuntimeError: If WaitGroup counter value goes below 0
done()[source]¶

Done decrements the WaitGroup counter by one.

wait()[source]¶

Wait blocks until the WaitGroup counter is zero.

Module contents¶

utils.asyncio provide utility classes with asynchronous behavior
